Simulating Continuous Values via Rejection Sampling from a Global Normal Distribution

Background

In this approach, we simulate continuous values from categorical intervals using rejection sampling based on a global normal distribution.

Each original bin (e.g., [100, 200]) acts as a domain for candidate values, but the acceptance is based on whether the candidate lies under the bell curve of a global normal distribution.

This allows us to simulate realistic values that:

  • Stay within original bounds
  • Enable continuous modeling like linear regression

Step-by-Step Summary

  1. Define a global normal distribution ( w (, ^2) ), where:
    • ( = ) midpoint of the entire observed range (e.g., 500)
    • ( = ), so 99.7% of values fall within bounds

For each row in the data:

  1. Sample a value ( x ) from the uniform distribution over the category range ( [a_i, b_i] )
  2. Sample ( y (0, f_{}) ), where ( f_{} ) is the maximum of the normal density (at ( x = ))
  3. Accept ( x ) if ( y < f(x) ), where ( f(x) ) is the normal density of ( w ) at ( x )

R Implementation

Sample dataset with interval (bin) categories

empirical_data <- data.frame( id = 1:6, category_min = c(100, 200, 150, 300, 200, 400), category_max = c(300, 300, 250, 500, 1000, 600) )

Step 1: Define global normal distribution

global_min <- min(empirical_data\(category_min) global_max <- max(empirical_data\)category_max)

global_mu <- (global_min + global_max) / 2 global_sigma <- (global_max - global_min) / 6

Step 2: Get max density of the global normal (at the mean)

f_max <- dnorm(global_mu, mean = global_mu, sd = global_sigma)

Step 3: Rejection sampling function

simulate_by_density_rejection <- function(min_val, max_val, mu, sigma, f_max) { repeat { x_candidate <- runif(1, min = min_val, max = max_val) y <- runif(1, min = 0, max = f_max) fx <- dnorm(x_candidate, mean = mu, sd = sigma)

if (y < fx) return(x_candidate)

} }

Step 4: Apply simulation per row

set.seed(42) empirical_data\(simulated_value <- mapply( simulate_by_density_rejection, empirical_data\)category_min, empirical_data$category_max, MoreArgs = list(mu = global_mu, sigma = global_sigma, f_max = f_max) )

Output simulated data

print(empirical_data)
